metadata.title: RECENT ADVANCES IN MAGNETIC NANOMATERIALS FOR IMPROVING ANALYTICAL PROCESSES

sections.text:
1
The recent advances involving the use of magnetic nanomaterials for improving different steps of analytical processes were revised. Magnetic nanomaterials are unique tools for the simplification of the sample preparation working under a solid phase (micro)extraction format, in order to provide the appropriated selectivity (cleanup) and sensitivity (preconcentration) of many new analytical methods, or improving this step in already existing ones. In addition, magnetic nanomaterials can play a key role for the separation processes (chromatographic or electrophoretic), in which some analytical methods are based. The third interesting incidence of magnetic
Page 1 of 30
2
nanomaterials are in the detection step, showing new advantageous possibilities. All these aspects are revised in this article.
KEYWORDS: Magnetic nanomaterials; sample preparation; separation; detection; revision.

sections.heading: 1. INTRODUCTION
sections.text:
Nanoscience and nanotechnology (N&N) are multidisciplinary areas in which
nanomaterials (NMs) are the mainstay. Research and development in them have been grown in recent years, presenting a great potential in the development of a wide variety nanostructures with new properties. It is reported in the literature different ways to systematically describe existing nanoparticles using classifications based on several criteria, such as their dimensionality, homogeneity, morphology, composition, and agglomeration [1]. One of the most common classification of nanostructures is based on the dimension [2]. It distinguishes four types of nanostructures: (i) nanoscale in one dimension, such as surfaces with nanometric thickness (e.g. graphene sheets); (ii) nanoscale in two dimensions, such as carbon nanotubes (CNTs), inorganic nanotubes, nanowires, biopolymers, etc.; (iii) nanoscale in three dimensions, which includes metallic nanopaticles (NPs) and their oxides such as Fe3O4, SiO2, Al2O3, TiO2, quantum dots (QDs), fullerenes, dendrimers; and (iv) classification of nanoscale at zero dimensions including nanoporous material, and composites with NPs. All of them, metallic and metal oxides NPs have a wide range of exploitation in analytical chemistry. Their versatile properties enable the development of nanostructure-based tools offering extremely promising improvements in the analytical basic properties of sensitivity, selectivity and reliability with respect to previous non-nanostructured designs. These tools are expected to be advantageously applied in many fields of socioeconomical relevance, such as environmental [3], food [4], clinical [5] and bioanalytical analysis [6].
Magnetic nanoparticles (MNPs) are a type of metal oxides NPs, which can be
handled by using an external magnetic field. The exploitation of their chemical, optical, electrical, thermal and magnetic properties at different analytical steps including
Page 2 of 30
3
sample treatment (extraction/clean-up, and preconcentration), chromatographic and CE techniques, and detection, contributes to the development of innovative analytical strategies or the improvement of the conventional ones, in order to achieve the required analytical properties (accuracy, precision, sensitivity, selectivity, speed and cost). MNPs can be used at different steps of analytical process as (i) synthesized (without functionalization), (ii) bonded on a support through a chemical reactions, (iii) incorporated into an inert solid, or (iv) modified with organic, inorganic and biochemical compounds to increase their physico-chemical properties. Table 1 shows the properties exploited at each step of the analytical process, the technique used and the improvements obtained in comparison with the use of conventional materials.
This article emphasizes the most recent progress in the use of MNPs in
analytical process over the period of 2012-2016. Its aims is to compile and revise representative literature on nanostructure-analytical based tools for the whole analytical process, from the sample treatment to optical and electrochemical transduction passing through analytes separation. In this respect, more information about applications of nanomaterials in general, and MNPs particularly, in analytical methods can be extracted from recent reviews [1,7-9].

sections.heading: 2. MAGNETIC NANOMATERIALS: SYNTHESIS AND CHARACTERIZATION.
sections.text:
MNPs are synthesized by a wide range of magnetic materials, such as iron,
nickel, cobalt, magnetite or maghemite, and their chemical compound. Iron oxides (Fe2O3 and Fe3O4), and their corresponding ferrites (e.g. MnFe2O4 and CoFe2O4), are the most commonly used for manufacture of MNPs because of their high magnetic moments, biological compatibility, and the simplicity of their preparation process, in comparison with other MNPs-based metals and alloys such as Mn3O4, Co, Ni, FePt, and FePd, which have a rapid oxidation in air and/or a potential cytotoxicity. Thus, ferrite oxide magnetite (Fe3O4), have been the focus of many recent works, because it is the most magnetic material of all the naturally occurring minerals on earth, and it is widely used in the form of superparamagnetic NPs for many diverse applications. Thank to the advantage of large surface area of particles with nanosize dimension, providing a
Page 3 of 30
4
high sorption capabilities, and strong response of the materials under an applied magnetic field, it must be remarked that, compared with traditional systems, the use of MNPs allows the simplification of the methods by the ease of handling, as well as the possibility of processing small amounts of samples. Therefore, different magnetic oxides, with a wide range of properties, have been synthesized using several methods, such as co-precipitation method [10], aerosol route [11], hydrothermal reaction [12], oxidative precipitation [13], organic precursor method [14], sonochemical decomposition [15], and sol–gel synthesis technique [16]. Inherently, bare magnetic cores show high non-specific binding, and they are only stable in solution at extreme pH values and low ionic strengths. In order to increase the pH range in which the MNPs are stable and obtaining specific interaction or binding with target analytes, these nanomaterials are coated with different compounds. Surface modification of MNPs can be used also to prevent aggregation, improving stability in suspensions, and to enhance the compatibility of nanoparticles with solid matrices or biological environments. It also provides means for further grafting or conjugating additional functional molecules. Usually this process involves three steps, including the synthesis of core (magnetite or maghemite), the coating of the magnetic core and the modification of the resultant core-shell structure. Figure 1 shows different types of shells and functional groups or final coatings, which can be anchored/coated to MNPs surfaces.
The characterization of nanostructures has become very important aspects of
the emerging field of the nanoparticles, where macroscopic properties are directly influenced by subtle nanostructural changes. In the case of MNPs, the sensitivity and specificity of detection are highly dependent on the particle size [17]. The prepared MNPs can be characterized using a wide variety of analytical techniques, such as dynamic light scattering (DLS), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), thermomagnetic measurement, dark-field microscopy, atomic force microscopy (AFM), and acoustic spectrometry measurement. Table 2 summarizes the advantages and disadvantages of these techniques used for the characterization of MNPs.
DLS, is one of the most popular methods used to determine the size of MNPs.
During the DLS measurement, the MNP suspension is exposed to a light beam
Page 4 of 30
5
(electromagnetic wave), and as the incident light impinges on the MNP, the direction and intensity of the light beam are both altered due to a process known as scattering [17]. TEM is one of the most powerful analytical tool used. It is based on detecting differences in electron density and allows observation of the size and shape of the MNPs, while SEM is used for the characterization of the morphological characteristics of MNPs. Thermomagnetic measurement extracts the average diameter as well as the size distribution of an ensemble of superparamagnetic nanoparticles. This transformation method makes use of an approximation to convert the measured temperature-dependent zero-field cooling (ZFC) magnetic moment, mZFC, into a probability distribution of the particle size base on the Néel model [18]. This method is an indirect measurement of particle size and relies on the underlying assumption of the mathematical model used to calculate the size distribution. Dark-field microscopy relies on direct visual inspection of the optical signal emitted from the MNP while it under goes Brownian motion. After the trajectories of each MNP over time t are recorded, the two dimensional mean- squared displacement <r2> = 4Dt is used to calculate the diffusion coefficient D for each particle. Later on, the hydrodynamic diameters can be estimated via the Stokes Einstein equation for the diffusion coefficients calculated for individual particles, averaging over multiple time steps [19]. As for AFM, besides the usual topographic analysis, magnetic imaging of a submicron sized MNP grown on GaAs substrate has been performed with magnetic force microscopy equipment [20]. The particle size and size distribution can also be measured with an acoustic spectrometer which utilizes the sound pulses transmitted through a particle suspension to extract the size-related information [21]. Based on the combined effect of absorption and scattering of acoustic energy, an acoustic sensor measures the attenuation frequency spectra in the sample. This attenuation spectrum is used to calculate the particle size distribution.
The surface area of modified or unmodified MNPs, their porosity and mean
diameter are determined by nitrogen adsorption–desorption porosimetry according to the Brunauer Emmett Teller (BET) method [22]. Common methods for detecting the surface functional groups of solids and investigating the adsorption mechanism of
Page 5 of 30
6
target metals are fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) [23] and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) [24].
Magnetic property is normally evaluated by a magnetometer, such as a
superconducting quantum interference device (SQUID) magnetometer and vibrating sample magnetometer (VSM). The superparamagnetism feature, which makes a magnetic solid respond to the external magnetic field and redisperse once the external magnetic field is removed, can be evaluated by magnetization curves. Kilinç et al. [23] studied the particles’ magnetic properties of FeO3 MNPs functionalized with MWCNTs using a VSM operating at maximum magnetic field. This technique was used in order to complete information obtained in the characterization of this magnetic nanomaterials by FTIR, TEM. However, there are other techniques, like thermo gravimetric analysis and Mossbauer spectrometry, which are employed for the evaluation of thermal stability and the explanation of magnetic particles behaviour as adsorbents, respectively [9].

sections.heading: 3. MAGNETIC NANOMATERIALS TO IMPROVE SAMPLE TREATMENT
sections.text:
Magnetic solid phase extraction (MSPE), which based on the use of magnetic or
magnetically modified adsorbents with paramagnetic properties, has been successfully applied to solve different analytical problems in analytical processes. In addition to its great extraction efficiency, MSPE simplifies the overall procedures, such as (i) the sorbent dispersion in sample solution instead of being packed into a SPE cartridge, (ii) the increase of the extraction rates by the improvement of the contact area between the sorbent and the sample, and (iii) the collection of sorbent material after the extraction by using an external magnetic field, which is a simpler alternative compared to centrifugation or filtration. The usefulness of MSPE has been based on two basic aspects. Firstly, the trend of the sorbents sizes from the micrometer to the nanometer scale resulting in an increase of the extraction efficiency thanks to the enhancement of the surface area of the particles. Secondly, improving the selectivity in extraction procedures by chemical modification of the MNPs surfaces.
Page 6 of 30
7
The general batch procedures, based on the use of MNPs and used in SPE, are
shown in Figure 2. In the first step, and after conditioning, MNPs are introduced in the sample solution containing the sample (analytes and interferences). Sorption of the analytes and/or the interferences takes place. According to the main purpose of the sample preparation, it can be distinguish two procedures in the second step. Thus, if the analytes must be preconcentrated to increase the sensibility, MNPs are associated with the analytes and this combination is concentrated by using and external magnetic field. After the separation of the remaining solution, the analytes are eluted from the MNPs using an appropriate solvent. Then, the determination step takes place. On the other hand, if the interferences must be removed for sample clean-up purposes, they are retained in the MNPs and, thus, concentrated in the magnetic field. The remaining solution is easily separated and analytes can be determined in it.
MNPs can also implemented in liquid-phase microextraction (LPME) for
retrieving solvents instead of using of time-consuming centrifugation [25]. Several applications using MNPs in LPME have appeared in the literature for the pretreatment of triazine herbicides and bisphenol A in waters [26,27], determination of aflatoxin M1 in milk samples [28], and the preconcentration of antidepressants in biological fluids [29]. In all these applications, MNPs are employed as sorbents for retrieving the extractant containing the analytes, which are finally desorbed. MNPs with large area and high sorption capacity can be isolated from the sample by an external magnetic field. In this way centrifugation is not needed and extraction solvents are not limited to high-density solvents [25].
Table 3 presents some recent examples of the application of different magnetic
nanomaterials for extraction of some analytes. These applications are classified following different types of shells and functional groups or final coatings reported in Figure 1.
A magnetite Fe3O4 core/zirconia shell (Fe3O4@ZrO2) nanoparticle material was
fabricated by the one-step co-precipitation method [33]. This nanocomposite was used to removal phosphate from water with high efficiency. The adsorption process was fast, and was not influenced substantially with the presence of competing anions. The adsorbed phosphate could be desorbed with NaOH treatment and the regenerated Fe3O4@ZrO2 could be repeatedly used. Extraction and enrichment technique based on
Page 7 of 30
8
ionic liquids (ILs) supported on magnetic nanoparticles (ILs-MNPs) of sulfonylurea herbicides was developped by Bouri et al. [35]. The ILs-Fe3O4/SiO2 MNPs used in the preconcentration step were synthesised, by incorporating N-methylimidazolium ionic liquid and Fe3O4 MNPs in a silica matrix, following the scheme presented in Figure 3. As this figure shows, the preparation method was required three steps, i.e. (i) preparation of nanoscale Fe 3 O 4 ; (ii) formation of silica shell to grow on the surface of Fe 3 O 4 and (iii) coating the shell with N-methylimidazolium ionic liquid. After reaction, the solid product was isolated by a magnet; then it was washed and dried under vacuum. The authors demonstrated that ILs immobilized on Fe3O4/SiO2 MNPs are suitable for extraction and preconcentration of sulfonylurea herbicides, due to the high surface area and the excellent adsorption capacity of these magnetic adsorbents.
The combination of CNTs with MNPs represents an interesting alternative,
which facilitates their use as sorbents in SPE, since an easier manipulation of CNTs can be achieved with an external magnetic field provided by a permanent magnet with a high-energy product. A novel extraction and enrichment technique based on MWCNTs and nano-C18 supported on magnetic nanoparticles (nanoC18-MWCNTs-MNPs) of zearalenone and its metabolites was developed by our research group [34]. The nanoC18-MWCNTs-MNPs used in the preconcentration step were synthesised by insitu high temperature decomposition of the precursor ferric ion, octadecyltricholorosilane (C18) and MWCNTs in ethylene glycol. TEM images, as it is shown in Figure 4, revealed that the composite is formed by deposition of the Fe2O3 and nano-C18 on the external walls of the MWCNTs.
Ionic surfactants (e.g. Triton, cetyltrimethylammonium bromide,CTAB,
octadecyltrimethylammonium, OTAB, and sodium dodecyl sulfate, SDS), were used to form hemimicelles and/or admicelles on the surface of MNPs by means of hydrophobic and/or electrostatic interactions. The ionic surfactants provided functionality (e.g. hydrophobic and electrostatic groups), for facilitating extraction in the SPE process. Alumina-coated magnetite nanoparticles (Fe 3 O 4 /Al 2 O 3 NPs) modified by the surfactant Triton X-114 was investigated for speciation of Cr(III) and Cr(VI) in water and soil samples [31]. The procedure was based on the reaction of chromium(III) with 1-(2- pyridilazo)-2-naphtol as a ligand, yielding a complex, which was entrapped “in situ” in
Page 8 of 30
9
the surfactant hemimicelles. Cr(VI) was reduced to Cr(III) by ascorbic acid, the system was applied to the total chromium. Cr(VI) was then calculated as the difference between the total Cr and the Cr(III) content.
Other interesting magnetic material used in sample treatment is magnetic
molecularly imprinted polymers (MMIPs) [8]. When magnetic components are encapsulated into MIPs, the resulting MMIP composite polymer will not only have a magnetically susceptible characteristic, but also the appropriated selectivity for the guest molecule. Additionally, they exhibited higher recognition selectivity and certain magnetic response to external magnetic fields. Because of a high selectivity of MMIPs, presenting in some cases similar or higher recognition levels compared with natural systems such as monoclonal antibodies. They have been classified as a suitable material for clean-up, selective separation and extraction of analytes from complex samples. Thus, the most important applications of MMIPs have been their use as selective adsorbents in analytical processes for clean-up and/or preconcentration of samples [40-48]. As it is demonstrated in many cases, exceptional characteristics of affinity and selectivity are added to the magnetism property of these materials. Bouri et al. [49] developed a simple method based on magnetic separation for selective extraction of dopamine and other structurally related catecholamines from environmental urine samples using MMIP as sorbent. The magnetic polymers were prepared using dopamine as template molecule, methacrylic acid as functional monomer, ethylene-glycol dimethacrylate as cross-linking agent and Fe3O4 magnetite as magnetic component. The prepared nanomaterial performed the purification and the separation in short time with LOD concentration at μM. Table 4 summarizes some recent published works (i.e. in the period between 2015 and 2016), in which MMIPs are used as sorbent material in environmental, bioanalytical, pharmaceutical or food applications. They have been classified as a suitable material for clean-up, selective separation and extraction of analytes from complex samples.
4. MAGNETIC NANOMATERIALS TO IMPROVE ANALYTE SEPARATION
Page 9 of 30
10
Another promising area of analytical process is the use of MNPs to improve the
resolution of the chromatographic and electrophoretic separations. In general, MNPs act as stationary or pseudo-stationary phases and the results are clearly better, in comparison with those obtained by the traditional sorbents. Using MNPs, due to their high capacity of adsorption, their long lifetime and their attractive surface chemistry, resolution is commonly enhanced. Therefore, MNMs present ideal properties for their integration as stationary and pseudostationary phases. For instance, these materials contain, at least, one dimension lower than 100 nm, and they can be included at low concentrations compared to traditional stationary or pseudostationary phases, and hence less than 1% of the total capillary volume is filled by MNPsb [1]. On the other hand, MNMs exhibit inherently large surface area to volume ratios and new chemical and physical properties, dependent to the nanoscale size, appear. These characteristics can be successfully exploited for MNMs as stationary phases. On the other hand, these materials present the ability to selectively interact with the capillary surface, the analyte or both, producing high mass transfers and greatly changing the parameters of a separation [1]. The large surface area can act as a platform for the adsorption of analytes or ligands, which differentially interact with the analytes occupying a small volume, and offering another mode of separation. Taken advantage of these features the precision and separation efficiency of the separation techniques can be improved. MNMs can either be introduced into the column or capillaries prior to the analytes (partial filling) or continuously introduced throughout the process of separation while having uniform mobility and not tampering with detection capabilities of the technique. Important developments in the separation of different substances has been achieved using HPLC, CE, and microchip CE, employing MNPs as components of the separation media. MNPs play different roles, such as permanent or dynamic capillary inner surface coatings in CE, stationary phases in CEC, pseudostationary phases in partial filling or continuous filling mode in MEKC, and as modifiers of stationary phases in liquid chromatography (LC). Now, the main trends in electromatoagraphy technology focus on new stationary phases and detection. Interesting development was undertaken in this way, in particular after the use of MNMs, showing good chemical stability, selectivity, separation efficiency, and overcoming the encountered
Page 10 of 30
11
drawbacks by conventional phases. In capillary electromatography, MNPs have been introduced to all types of stationary phases, packed CEC, open- tubular CEC (OT-CEC) and monolithic column CEC.
Qin et al. [50-51] explored MNPs and carboxyl functionalized MNPs with UiO-67
metal-organic framework (MOFs) core-shell composites as a novel stationary phase for LC. The use of MNPs UiO-67 core-shell composites as stationary phase combines the advantages of a thin, homogenous UiO-67 shell showing fast kinetics and good separation efficiency with the advantages of silica MNPs offering high mechanical robustness and moderate pressure drop. In other work [52] the same authors used other MOFs (MIL-100(Fe)) coated onto the surface of MNPs via a liquid-phase epitaxy method. Chromatographic columns packed with these synthesized MNPs offer improved separation performance for aromatic hydrocarbons with increasing water content of the mobile phases (MeOH/H2O), due to the change of the affinity strength between the analytes and the crystalline MOF-based solid phase. Magnetic stationary phase exhibits high adsorption capacities for aromatic molecules compared to the previous reported metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) used in chromatography. This important finding should have a significant impact on applying MOFs as adsorbents in industrial separation and purification processes. Zhu et al. developed OT-CEC column with core/shell magnetic nanoparticle coating as stationary phase by using the magnetic effect of permanent magnets to immobilize the magnetic nanoparticles with ion-exchange mechanism onto the inner wall of the capillary [53]. Mixture of five organic acids was used as the marker sample to evaluate the OT-CEC system, and the relative column efficiency of anthranilic acid reaches 220 000 plates/m. CarrascoCorrea et al. incorporated vinylized iron oxide magnetic nanoparticles (VMNPs) onto polymethacrylate monolithic columns to develop novel stationary phases with enhanced separation performance [54]. The synthetized magnetic materials were applied to the CEC separation of test mixtures of alkylbenzenes and organophosphorous pesticides with increased retention and high column efficiency in comparison to the control monolith. The higher retention seems to be due to the increase of the surface area of the monolith, produced by the presence of VMNPs. The hybrid monolithic columns also showed a satisfactory batch-to-batch reproducibility. The intrinsic characteristics of VMNPs such as large surface area and its feasible
Page 11 of 30
12
dispersion in polymerization mixture make the nanocomposites reported in this work, attractive materials for the enhanced separation performance of small molecules in chromatographic techniques. Packed column involving magnetically immobilized frits represents a robust alternative to common sintered frit CEC columns [55]. Their efficiencies are comparable while the fabrication process is straightforward and reproducible. Additional features include retaining of the polymer coating of the capillary so as to avoid the fragility at frit sections as associated with sintered columns, and that polymer-based packing material can be used as it is no longer necessary to create an inlet frit by heating. They are advantageous over approaches based on monolithic columns where surface modification and functionalization are difficult to achieve. This feature offers great potential, especially in the pharmaceutical field, as commercially available chiral stationary phases can be packed into capillaries for drug analysis. The magnetically assisted CEC is also promising for construction of chip-based CEC where creation of retaining frits and packing of particular materials into separation channels remains a demanding challenge.
MNPs can be also introduced into the cannel of CE-microchip as represented in
Figure 5. Chip-based enantioselective OT-CEC was developed employing bovine serum albumin (BSA)-conjugated graphene oxide–magnetic nanocomposites (GO/Fe3O4) as stationary phase [56]. BSA was immobilized on GO/Fe3O4 through hydrophobic, π-π stacking interactions and hydrogen bonding to form a multicomponent nanocomposite and subsequently organized by an external magnetic field in the channel. The authors validated the electrochromatographic enantioselectivity and reproducibility of the constructed OT-CEC microdevice by chiral separation of tryptophan enantiomers obtaining a good performance in terms of sensitivity, repeatability, and efficiency for enantiomers separation. BSA-conjugated Fe3O4@Au nanoparticles (Fe3O4@AuNPs) nanocomposites used as stationary phase in separation channel of microchip capillary electrophoresis (MCE) was used for successful separation of chiral amino acids [57]. The resultant magnetic stationary phase not only have the magnetism of Fe3O4 NPs that make them easily but also have the larger surface and excellent biocompatibility of Au shell, which can incorporate much more biomolecules and well maintain their biological activity. Kim et al. developed a novel ELISA format, stationary liquid-phase lab-on-a-chip (SLP-LOC), in which contents of the sample and detection chambers were
Page 12 of 30
13
efficiently separated by the channel, and MNPs-bound molecules were specifically transported from the sample chamber to the detection chamber by moving a magnet [58]. The SLP LOC was also successfully applied to a saxitoxin (STX) immunoassay using simple process (i.e., moving a magnet below the LOC) instead of complicated liquid handling steps involving washing and substrate addition.

sections.heading: 5. MAGNETIC NANOMATERIALS TO IMPROVE ANALYTICAL DETECTION
sections.text:
The use of MNPs for improving the detection is another aspect more and more
reported in the last years. MNPs can be involved in this point of analysis by their involvement in development of electrodes or MNPs-modified electrodes to detect chemical or biochemical substances. Antibodies or other substances, according to the type of the target analytes, can modify the designed electrodes to successfully achieve the analytical requirements. The remarkable properties of the modified nanoelectrodes are their high selectivity, high activity and strong adsorption capability, which are broadly used in the detection of trace amount of substances in different matrices, and extended to the non-easily detectable analytes by conventional electrodes. This exploitation became one of the important research fields in modern analytical chemistry. The use of MNPs in manufacturing the electrodes composites (where they act as mediators), are dramatically increasing. The "new" electrodes are important because of their numerous advantages, including large surface area, low resistance to electronic transmission and the ability to absorb chemically (bio) chemical analytes, which make them very attractive and useful in the electrochemical classical determinations. The roles that play the MNPs in this field are the minimization of deterioration of the electrode surfaces, the increase of the electrocatalytic activity and the simplification immobilization process of biomolecules (such as enzymes, and antibodies) in the surface of the electrode [59]. In this way, hybrid MNMs are thrived by the combination of Fe3O4NPs and metallic, silica, carbon and polymeric NPs for the manufacture of electrodes, thereby finding that some electrocatalytic properties thereof increase [60]. Many works based on the modification of electrodes by MNPs were developed, in order to detect hydrazine and hydroxylamine [61], nitrite [62] and
Page 13 of 30
14
2,4,6-trinitrotoluene (TNT) in water samples [63], organophosphorus [64] , allergens [65], Ochratoxin A [66] and gluten [67] in food samples, dopamine [68], uric [69] and mefenamic acid [70], phenazopyridine [71], morphine [72] and hemoglobin [73] in human blood, plasma and urine. Relevant information dealing with the preparation and the application of these electrochemical sensors is presented in Table 5.
The fabrication procedure of magnetic electrodes consist in various steps. One
example of preparation of grapheme oxides AuNPs-MIPs (MGO@AuNPs-MIPs) electrodes was proposed by Li et al. [74]. The composite of MGO@AuNPs was first synthesized using coprecipitation and self-assembly technique. Then, the template molecules were absorbed at the MGO@AuNPs surface due to their excellent affinity, and subsequently, selective copolymerization of methacrylic acid and ethylene glycol dimethacrylate was further achieved at the MGO@AuNPs surface. After template molecules were extracted from imprinted polymers film, an electrochemical sensor was constructed for highly sensitive and selective detection of dibutyl phthalate (DBP). Recently, Fe3O4-NPs attracted much attention in the fabrication of biosensing systems, due to their unique properties, such as biocompatibility and signal amplification, and their ability to bind covalently to antibodies via their functional groups [59]. Jorda et al. developed a electrochemical immunosensor based on magnetic beads and carbon screen-printed electrodes for determination of ocratoxin A in coffees samples [66]. The MNPs were used as antibody support and enzyme horseradish peroxidase as tracer. Chen et al. developed a sensitive strategy for tumour cells assay based on cell-SELEX aptamers by using bio-bar-code MNPs as an amplification station [75]. The system advance the topic of DNA SDR through toehold exchange reaction and RCA by assembling a large number of Ru (bpy)3 2+ derivative probes, which associates with sensitive electrochemiluminescence readout techniques. The feasibility of this assay was evaluated by detecting Ramos cells spiked in complex samples and human blood samples.
The absorbance and fluorescence detection are usually used in the analytical
field as a routine measure, due to it’s easy handling and rapid response obtained by a simple instrumentation, in a rapid way with a high sensitivity (detection limit which can be fairly low) and satisfactory reproducibility. Even in this routine instrument, MNMs can be involved in the detection. In fact, they have been used to develop many works
Page 14 of 30
15
involving several conventional organic dye molecules (e.g., pyrene, rhodamine, and fluorescein isothiocyanate, FITC), and fluorescent inorganic nanoparticles (e.g., quantum dots,QDs, to be incorporated inside the MNPs). For instance, functionalized MNPs, which act as colorimetric and switchable chemosensor for sensing and separating Zn2+ and CN- in aqueous solutions [76]. This fluorescent magnetic nanosensor was prepared from adamantine-modified fluorescein and β-cyclodextrinmodified Fe3O4/SiO2 via host-guest interactions. Wang et al. developed a fluorescent and colorimetric magnetic microspheres as nanosensors for determination of Hg2+ in water samples [77]. The fluorescent sensing TSRh6G-b-cyclodextrin fluorophore/adamantane-modified inclusion complex magnetic nanoparticles (TFIC MNPs) have been synthesized via the cooperation of a host–guest interaction and sol– gel grafting reaction. Fluorescence and UV-visible spectra have shown that the resultant multifunctional nanoparticle sensors exhibit selective ‘turn-on’ type fluorescent enhancements and a clear colour change from light brown to pink with Hg2+.
Fluorescent-magnetic nanoparticles (FMNPs) are also used in the bioanalytical
field, due to their ease handling and dual detection ability (i.e., fluorescent and magnetic modes). FMNPs can be used to diagnosis and therapy of a target cancer cell (cell 1) in the presence of the other cells (cell 2 and 3) as illustrated in the Figure 6 [78]. The colloidal FMNPs conjugated with specific targeting groups (i.e., antibodies), can be incubated with the mixture of cancer cells followed by magnetic separation and two detection modes (for instance, magnetic resonance imaging, MRI, and fluorescence analysis). According to the specific antigen labeled on the cell surfaces, the circulating cancer cells can be detected. The high potential FMNPs can be used as a therapeutic agent based on magnetolytic therapy.
Zhang et al. synthetized GdS coated CdTe nanoparticles (CdTe@GdS NPs) as
multimodal agents for fluorescence (FL) and T1-weighted MRI [79]. These nanoparticles obtain both prominent fluorescent and paramagnetic properties by coating the GdS shell on the surface of CdTe core via a simple room-temperature route in aqueous solution directly, which allow them to be employed as FL/MRI dual-modal imaging contrast agents. In addition, with the conjugation of folic acid, the nanoparticles were successfully used for tumor-targeted FL/MRI dual-modal imaging in vitro and in vivo. In
Page 15 of 30
16
general, the applications presented above demonstrates the important roles that MNPs play in the detection step, and it may be concluded that MNMs can be involved in any level of analysis process and for many purposes, while adapting the tools to the corresponding objectives by the modification of MNPs (functionalization).

sections.heading: 6. CONCLUSIONS
sections.text:
MNPs are interesting tools for developing new analytical methods or improving
the existing ones. The examples shown in this article demonstrate that the MNPs simplify the sample treatment, and clearly contribute to the selectivity and sensitivity requirements of the present analytical problems. In this case, the sorbent does not need to be packed into the cartridge (as in the conventional SPE), the separation phase can be carried out in an easy way by applying an external magnetic field resulting in short time in the sample preparation, and the MNPs showed a great stability, with possibilities of reusability for several times. The usefulness of MNPs, involved in the sample preparation step, has been very well demonstrated in many clean-up and preconcentration procedures. However, some disadvantages and limitations of these materials must be stated. Thus, sample treatment and separation/detection are carried out off-line, involving human manipulation without any automated commercially device, as well as some additional limitation associated to their properties. The improvements of the physicochemical properties of MNPs and development of easy protocol for synthesis and functionalization of MNPs will introduce interesting advantages and new possibilities. Therefore, it is expected that producing marketable adsorbents with magnetic property for a selective extraction of specific analyte of interest can be planned in the future. Other aspect that needs to be improved in the future is the on-line coupling of MSPE with analytical separation techniques such as LC, GC and CE. Without any doubt, this arrangement can reduce the analysis time, sample contamination, and analyte losses, as well as improve the accuracy and precision. Recently Maya et al. [80] developed a fully automatic system enabled the dispersion of MNPs throughout the sample volume, and the subsequent
Page 16 of 30
17
magnetic collection, washing, elution, and online spectrophotometric detection of malachite green in water and fish samples. These authors conclude in this work, that the future research will be directed on-line coupling this automatic system with LC and GC.
The analysis of solid samples, in which all analysis and sample extraction
procedures take place in a closed and automated system, is other aspect that can be taken into account in the future. It can be carried out by on-line coupling of MSPEseparation technique with other sample preparation techniques, such as supercritical fluid extraction (SFE), subcritical water extraction (SWE) and ultrasound-assisted extraction (UAE).
Due the limited research being on integration of MNPs as stationary phase in LC
and GC, more separation methods should be involved in this area. Using MNPs it will be possible to prepare new stationary phase with large surface area to volume ratios and new chemical and physical properties that can give efficient separations and selectivity.
In the case of use of MNPs to improve detection, methods have been
developed based on electrochemical detection mainly, and very few used for the detection by SPR and fluorescence spectroscopy. Therefore, efforts are needed on the development of new optical sensors and biosensors using MNPs.

The support given through an “INCRECYT” research contract to M. Zougagh is also acknowledged.

Recently, Fe3O4-NPs attracted much attention in the fabrication of biosensing systems, due to their unique properties, such as biocompatibility and signal amplification, and their ability to bind covalently to antibodies via their functional groups [59].

metadata.abstractText: The recent advances involving the use of magnetic nanomaterials for improving different steps of analytical processes were revised. Magnetic nanomaterials are unique tools for the simplification of the sample preparation working under a solid phase (micro)extraction format, in order to provide the appropriated selectivity (cleanup) and sensitivity (preconcentration) of many new analytical methods, or improving this step in already existing ones. In addition, magnetic nanomaterials can play a key role for the separation processes (chromatographic or electrophoretic), in which some analytical methods are based.
